awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Transparent Flexible Quasi-Ceramic Intelligent Multifunctional Coatings for Corrosion and Biofouling Protection
awd_abstract_narration:
This SBIR Phase II project aims to develop and commercialize a transparent, thin multifunctional coating for corrosion and biofouling prevention on coated surface. Its environmentally friendly product will be an efficient ready-to-use single component product that can be applied with ease, and would dry in ambient conditions without the need for external heating equipment. The global annual expenditure to mitigate corrosion is in the range of $2.5 trillion, roughly equal to 3.4% of the world's GDP. Protecting assets from corrosion is, hence, a critical requirement for all the industries. A broad range of applications can benefit from this coating technology such as aviation industry where removal of toxic chromium compounds from coating procedures is of high priority, automobile manufacturing where extended corrosion protection to vehicles without using toxic treatments is constantly sought, structural engineering where providing long life protection to bridges is always needed, marine engineering where protecting ships from corrosion and not contributing to ecological imbalance is long sought, military where minimizing the maintenance downtime of tanks and guns is of prime importance, hospitals that are interested in longer lasting medical implants, and paints and coating industry that is desiring removal of volatile organic components from their paints and coatings. The proposed coating is expected to offer scratch resistance and oleophobic characteristics in addition to corrosion protection. The initial success of this project will result in two high-volume products.


This project aims to develop a specialized single-part, ready-to-use, nominally bioceramic liquid coating for protection against corrosion and fouling activities. On application over desired surface, this transparent liquid transforms into hard-yet-flexible coating. This thin coating composition consists of in-place generated nanoparticles of organometallic compounds in the 3D network of polysilsesquioxane. The reactivity of the precursor to coating is designed such that material can react with substrates in ambient conditions and dries to solid film without the need of any external heating. The hardened coating adheres to most surfaces including metals, ceramics, plastics, glasses, and wood. The optimum thickness of coating is approximately ten microns and can impart various desired surface functionalities to the coated object. In this project, efforts are directed towards optimization of current composition to be compatible with broad range of commercially available topcoat materials. The optimized coating composition will be subjected to a rapid properties screening before third party testing, validation and approvals. An extensive field testing will be conducted in collaboration with potential customers. This innovative coating technology will initially result into two products that can be used in place of carcinogenic hexavalent chromium compounds that are currently in use for the corrosion protection of metals. While one of the products would act as a corrosion prevention compound that can adhere to commercial topcoat paints, the other would act as self-cleaning coating to prevent biofouling activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
FINAL REPORT SUMMARY

 

This document summarizes the proposed objectives, accomplishments, conclusion drawn from our work in Phase-II and supplement. In this phase we were focusing on the following three coatings:

(a) Single component, thin transparent corrosion resistant metal surface treatment that could adhere with commercial topcoats

(b) Single component, thin transparent coating with antifouling characteristics

(c) Single component, long lasting antimicrobial coating

The FL1011A (FLYCO) provides prolonged corrosion protection in combination with commercial topcoats; while FL1011B (AVICO) provides protection to surfaces without topcoats along with antifouling characteristics. Similarly, the FL2011 or INVESIL (INVCO) could be applied to almost any surface and shall provide long term antimicrobial characteristics to the coated objects.

OBJECTIVE 1.1: OPTIMIZATION OF COATINGS

Originally, few commercial topcoats adhered well to FLYCO. It was discovered that surface energy of the dry coating was approximately 28 dyne/cm while for optimum universal topcoat adhesion; surface energy must be more than 30 dyne/cm. The first few months of this program were devoted to the optimization of compositions with improved surface energy and reduced contact angle.

OBJECTIVE 1.2: TESTING OF MODIFIED COATINGS

Important tests like salt spray as per ASTM B117, crosscut and pull adhesion, solvent rub and nanoindentation provided information about the changes in the properties of modified material. The corrosion protection was checked in salt spray test (ASTM B117). Similarly, crosscut test (ASTM D3359-17), adhesion pull test (ASTM 4541-17), nanoindentation (ISO 14577) were accomplished. The cross-section imaging using Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FESEM) showed packing arrangement of the coatings. 

OBJECTIVE 2.1: SPECIFICATION BASED APPROVALS

The AMS 3175A testing was accomplished with non-chromated surface pretreatment prior to painting. The modified FLYCO was sent to a third party who is approved by the industry to conduct such specification-based testing.

OBJECTIVE 2.2:  PREPARATION OF DOCUMENTS

The GHS compliance Safety Data Sheets (SDS) and Technical Data Sheet (TDS) were generated. All the other necessary documents for packaging and shipping were prepared.

OBJECTIVE 3.1: CUSTOMER IDENTIFICATION AND BETA TESTING

Our company identified a beta customer who applied our products on an aircraft interior. A US Army Lab and two US Navy labs have tested our products and compared them to the state-of-the-art. Four government reports have been published on our products. We have also identified several niche markets and sold products for the applications.

OBJECTIVE 3.2: DATA REDUCTION AND REPORT GENERATION

As proposed, data was stored systematically, and the program manager was updated monthly on the progress of the project. Three Patents (one USA, one European and one Asian) were awarded to this technology and four government reports along with three articles were published during this program.

CONCLUSIONS

Here in this research project, we have developed and demonstrated three coatings. The applications of coatings are corrosion protection, anti-ice adhesion and antimicrobial. The FLYCO coating that was originally known as FL1011A (or FLORYL) can adhere strongly to metallic surfaces and can accept commercial topcoat products. The AVICO coating that was originally known as FL1011B (or AVIRAL) creates low surface energy that restricts adhesion of foreign objects including ice or snow. The INVCO coating that was originally known as FL2011A (or INVESIL) can bond to most surfaces and provide long-term antimicrobial characteristics to the applied objects.

All the three coatings are extensively tested and verified by the third-party approval labs, including government agencies. The FLYCO has been verified for the application in the aviation industry (AMS3175A non chrome approved) and AVICO has been tested by US Navy Lab as a superior anti-icing coating. Similarly, INVCO has been verified by the US Army Lab to show long term antimicrobial activity.

FUTURE PLANS

The three coatings discussed here have been commercialized and being sold to different customers. Company is moving forward to build their own full scale manufacturing facility in USA.

 


Last Modified: 07/12/2023
Modified by: Anupama Chaturvedi
